The Pawnbroker (1964)

A Jewish pawnbroker, victim of Nazi persecution, loses all faith in his fellow man until he realizes too late the tragedy of his actions.

This was one of the first films to deal with the effects of Nazi Germany's concentration camps on their survivors. Sol Nazerman, operator of a pawn shop, and a concentration camp survivor faces a horrid internal conflict. Being engulfed in a New York ghetto Environment, Sol suffers flashbacks. The flashbacks juxtapose concentration camp treatment with ghetto neighborhood treatment. His internal conflicts between submitting to the same injustices he and his family suffered or resisting the injustice peak at the end of the filmWritten by Alexander Nicolas 

 

Please purchase your ticket when you RSVP through the link or at bjff.org

100% Critics Rating on Rottentomatoes

Based on a book by Edward Lewis Wallant, The Pawnbroker features the skilled camera work of Boris Kaufman, who had previously worked with director Sidney Lumet on films such as 12 Angry Men (1957) and Long Day's Journey Into Night (1962). The score is composed by Quincy Jones, who would contribute to Lumet's 1978 musical, The Wiz. ~ Kristie Hassen, Rovi

Following the film, we have reservations for a discussion at Fugakyu.

 

The response to our idea to host a small group discussion at a 'quiet' restaurant was so overwhelming that it became impossible to send invitations.  We are going to try posting as an event.  

We've managed to make reservations for two, separate, tables so we can expand the number without creating a big group.  

Please purchase your ticket as this film will almost certainly sell out.

See you at the movie,

John
